text: Acura's RL flagship sedan never caught
fire in the marketplace that's due in
part to tepid styling and their own TL
an impressive car that costs a lot less
I'm Tom bulk with driven for the New
York Times the successor to RL is a bit
bigger and gains an extra letter yes our
LX is what Ralph Lauren calls his
outdoor clothing line then there's this
badge it would be easy to believe it
represents some sort of fancy all-wheel
drive system but this is a front drive
car that cute little acronym stands for
precision all-wheel steer now there is
an all-wheel drive version of the RL X
coming in the form of a hybrid at high
speeds Acura claims that pause improves
stability by turning the rear wheels in
the same direction as the front watch
very carefully see during low speeds and
u-turns they move in opposite directions
pause cannot be turned off so it's tough
to gauge what difference it really makes
our LX handles well for a front drive
car discerning pilots know that they can
get rear or all-wheel drive with every
other premium brand always pragmatic
Acura sticks with a v6 for now
direct-injected the velvety 3.6 liter
makes 310 horsepower and can shut down
half the cylinders for improved fuel
efficiency
there are six speeds in the gearbox most
others in class offers seven or eight
RLX moves out briskly enough hitting 60
miles an hour in just over six seconds
the ride quality is firm but comfortable
pretty popular setting these days a
little surprising sharp bumps can really
be felt blame it on the low-profile
tires the cabin is quiet and fuel
economy is decent I saw 28 miles per
gallon during a short road trip
the official EPA rating is 20 City 31
highway sober and handsome the interior
is well crafted with the kind of
materials expected in a car that starts
at 51 grand this fully optioned advanced
model that goes for sixty one three has
seats that warm and chill you might buy
RLX just to get the Krell audio system
it's that good
Acura's touchscreen interface is
reminiscent of the ones found in Civic
and Accord it's not always elegant to
use passengers should be able to get
comfortable back here the seats are very
nicely sculpted and there's a good
amount of room but like a lot of luxury
cars these days the center position is
raised up so there is the potential of a
crick in your neck or your hair restyled
against your well back sides will get a
warm feeling and rear passengers can
control the sunshade oh and these could
be the most elaborate found on any car
at any price ever wondered what happens
if you accidentally lock the keyless
ignition fob in the trunk
don't ask me how I discovered that the
seats don't split and fold skis can be
loaded but snowboards are denied luggage
is protected from crushing hinge arms
the cargo hold is average in size RLX
scores a six in the tipi trunk test
brilliant LED lighting and an a/v system
that gives traffic conditions on surface
streets is compelling styling is not the
sheet metal doesn't offer much for the
eye to remember Acura seems fiercely
determined to redefine subtlety they're
cool logical approach to luxury keeps
RLX from becoming a car to lust after I
would pause and wait for the more
powerful all-wheel drive hybrid to see
if Acura steers RLX in a more
distinctive direction
